title: How safe is bare-knuckle boxing as it fights for mainstream appeal?
description: A new BBC documentary looks at the rise of bare-knuckle boxing as fighter Liam 'Rocky' Rees tells BBC Sport why he loves the adrenaline.
fullText:
"One punch could change your life. But I love the sport."

Bare-knuckle boxer Liam Rees is aware of the dangers when he steps onto the canvas.

The Welshman juggles his day job as a carpenter with the demands of a sport so visibly brutal it has stayed in the shadows of combat sports for much of its existence.

Slumped in a chair moments after losing his light-middleweight world title at the Vale Sport Arena, Cardiff, the Swansea native's wife Emma gently implores her bloodied partner to give up the sport.

But nothing can replace the buzz for him.

"You've got so much adrenaline pumping through your body in that ring," he tells BBC Sport.

At licensed bare-knuckle events, fighters go toe-to-toe on surfaces half the size of a professional gloved boxing ring - which means there is nowhere to hide.

There are more cuts, bruises and knockouts - which is exactly the appeal for some fans.

After overcoming substance-abuse issues, the 31-year-old was introduced to the emerging combat sport by a trainer in his boxing gym.

He made his bare-knuckle boxing debut in 2023, going on to become a two-time light-middleweight world champion in BKB.

During camp, Rees trains three times a day, five days a week, forgoing seeing his two children on weekdays.

He does not earn enough from the sport to quit his carpentry business. His goal is to leave a "legacy, just to prove to the city I've done something for them".

Bare-knuckle is the oldest form of boxing but became associated with unlicensed fights on wastelands after The Marquess of Queensberry rules were introduced in 1867, which insisted on gloves.

However, in the past decade, licensed events have grown. As per data from BoxRec, there were only 21 licensed bare-knuckle bouts in 2015. Last year, the figure was more than 1,000 across 21 countries.

Rees fights under the banner of Bare Knuckle Boxing (BKB) promotions ‚Äì one of two major international promotions who host licensed bouts, alongside US-based Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship (BKFC).

Attendances at BKB venues are capped at 2,000 and the organisation's president David Tetreault says they generally sell out.

Broadcast in more than 60 countries, BKB has partnerships with the likes of VICE TV and TalkSport.

Retired boxing world champions Lee Selby, Paulie Malignaggi and James DeGale have all crossed into bare-knuckle boxing as the popularity grows.

However, Luke Griggs, chief executive of brain injury charity Headway, said he is "hugely concerned" about its rise and the "glamourisation of a sport that's going to be taken out into the streets".

In a new film, BBC Sport investigates the realities of a sport that is slowly becoming more popular, and the people at the heart of it.

Gloves are off - the rise of bare-knuckle boxing

It was only in 2018 that the first sanctioned bare-knuckle bout for 130 years took place in the US state of Wyoming.

The US has seen the biggest growth in the sport. There were at least 65 events in the States in 2025. The UK is second, with 31 events last year.

Tetreault told BBC Sport that 90% of BKB bouts end in knockout or technical knockout and claimed that the fast nature of the sport appeals particularly to Gen Z and millennial fans.

Some 50% of their audience on social media fall into those younger demographics.

When Malignaggi defeated Tyler Goodjohn by split decision at the John Charles Centre for Sport in Leeds last October, the crowd was studded with boxing luminaries, including former multiple super-middleweight world champion Carl Froch, former two-time featherweight world champion Josh Warrington and former two-weight world champion Natasha Jonas.

"It's a blood sport, people do have a blood thirst to watch this sport," Malignaggi says.

"It's more action packed and I think the misconceptions are going to slowly go away once people watch it more and more."

Jonas says she was "impressed by the set-up", but doubts she will ever compete in it.

Boxing promoter Eddie Hearn says while there is clearly an audience for the sport, "it's a little bit barbaric for me, I am a boxing purist".

'Entertaining' or 'irresponsible'? The rise of bare-knuckle boxing

An inside look at what it's like to fight in bare-knuckle fight

Although bare-knuckle boxing seems more brutal than its gloved counterpart, Tetreault claims that there are misconceptions.

"The fighters have to be taking care of their hands. They can't hit as hard," he said.

Whereas professional gloved boxing events involve a maximum of 12, three-minute rounds, in BKB, bouts are capped at a maximum of six, three-minute rounds while BKFC bouts involve two-minute rounds.

Tetreault cites the shorter duration of bare-knuckle fights as another mitigating factor when answering safety concerns.

"The difference is it's not the continual punching," he said.

Dr. Louis Durkin, president of the Association of Ringside Physicians, who is also a stitch doctor for BKB, shared data from a study conducted by the ARP in 2025. It looked at 2,000 fighters across BKB and BKFC and compared the rates of injury with previously conducted studies from gloved boxing and MMA.

The study found that the percentage of concussions was lower in bare-knuckle boxing (5% in BKFC and 4.76% in BKB) than gloved boxing (12%) and MMA (14.7%).

Conversely, there was a much higher rate of laceration found in bare-knuckle boxing (34.3% in BKFC and 35.9% in BKB) than gloved boxing (8.7%) and MMA (13.5%).

However, consultant neurosurgeon Peter Hamlyn says there is a lack of data in general in bare-knuckle boxing.

"Hitting someone with equal power with an ungloved fist delivers more energy to the head, more brain injury," he explained.

"However, you've then got all those confounding factors - it hurts your hands, so you tend to hold back a bit, and there is the number of blows that are landed, the number of rounds.

"When you add that all together, you end up actually with a conclusion that reads something like, 'I don't know'."

Hamlyn also mentioned that it is difficult to make conclusive judgements on brain injury in the short term.

"The difficulty we've had in sport is that that data doesn't emerge until they're in their later life," he said.

"If you're deliberately trying to cause a brain injury in order to win a bout, that can't be right," Griggs said.

The first BKB event of 2026 will take place at London's Indigo on 21 February.

"Part of what we're doing in 2026 is we're going to be coming to the bigger cities," Tetreault said.

He is convinced that bare-knuckle boxing can go mainstream.

"We're seeing it with our ticket sales," he reasoned. "We're seeing it with our ratings. Part of our roadmap is building out bigger mega fights with some star power."

Meanwhile, Rees' future in the sport is uncertain. Since losing his title to Filipino former UFC fighter Rolando Dy, he says he is in "semi-retirement".

"Bare-knuckle's a full-time job," he said.

"I've missed out on too much of my kids' lives. I'd love to get involved again, but we'll see.

"Let's say I'm on a long vacation at the minute."

title: UK Athletics pleads guilty to corporate manslaughter
description: UK Athletics plead guilty to the corporate manslaughter of UAE Paralympian Abdullah Hayayei who died in 2017 after a metal cage fell on him while training in London.
fullText:
UK Athletics has pleaded guilty to the corporate manslaughter of Paralympian Abdullah Hayayei.

Hayayei died aged 36 after a metal cage fell on him while training at Newham Leisure Centre, London in July 2017.

UK Athletics pleaded not guilty to the charge in March 2025 but entered a fresh plea on Friday at an Old Bailey hearing.

Keith Davies, the head of sport for the 2017 World Para-athletics Championships, also pleaded guilty to a health and safety charge, having previously denied gross negligence manslaughter.

Prosecutor Karen Robinson asked the court to set a two-day sentencing hearing in early June, confirming the prosecution would not seek a trial and the outstanding charges would be dealt with at the conclusion of the sentencing.

Davies, 78, was granted continued bail on the condition he liaise with the Probation Service for a pre-sentence report.

Hayayei was training for the World Para-athletics Championships in London at the time of the incident.

The United Arab Emirates thrower had been set to compete in the F34 shot put, discus and javelin events.

Hayayei, a father of five, finished sixth in the javelin and seventh in the shot put when making his Paralympic debut at Rio 2016.

London 2017 was due to be his second appearance at a worlds. At the 2015 event in Doha, Qatar, Hayayei finished fifth in the discus and eighth in the shot put.

A moment of silence was held in honour of Hayayei during the opening ceremony at London Stadium.

title: How to win friends and influencers: Labour‚Äôs new social media strategy is a step into the future | Kirsty Major
description:
There was a backlash when No 10 invited online content creators inside its doors. But in a fast-changing media landscape, this solves two problems at once
Last year, No 10 took an unprecedented step: it invited content creators to cross the threshold of Downing Street.
Naturally, the creators all filmed themselves outside the famous door. Once inside, their most treasured possessions, their phones, were taken from them and exchanged for government-approved devices, so they could continue to take photos and record video without breaching security guidelines. At the reception, creators from areas as wide as science, education and travel took part in a networking session at the heart of government.
fullText:
There was a backlash when No 10 invited online content creators inside its doors. But in a fast-changing media landscape, this solves two problems at once

Last year, No 10 took an unprecedented step: it invited content creators to cross the threshold of Downing Street.

Naturally, the creators all filmed themselves outside the famous door. Once inside, their most treasured possessions, their phones, were taken from them and exchanged for government-approved devices, so they could continue to take photos and record video without breaching security guidelines. At the reception, creators from areas as wide as science, education and travel took part in a networking session at the heart of government.

This was one of a number of events in 2025. There were also off-the-record breakfasts to talk about how creators might collaborate with the government to reach new and younger audiences. A large part of the work being done by No 10‚Äôs New Media Unit was aimed at working with financial education creators to help share new policies being launched by the Treasury.

Financial content creators were invited to speeches and briefings for the biggest political events of the year. When Anna Brading, a personal finance content creator, entered the No 10 briefing room for the spring statement, she could hardly believe it. Having three kids at a young age meant that she spent her time raising a family and making ends meet by tutoring maths on the side. As she managed her family‚Äôs money, she began posting tips online for other mums. Now she was in the room that public health experts had updated the public from during the pandemic. ‚ÄúThe day I walked in that room, I had to take a minute,‚Äù she says.

This article includes content provided by Instagram. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content, click 'Allow and continue'.

There was, of course, a backlash as some journalists felt that these creators didn‚Äôt have the expertise or clout to hold the government to account, but this may be one of the few areas in which No 10 is getting it right. The unit is attempting to address two unavoidable truths: one, people don‚Äôt trust politicians; two, more people are now getting their news from content platforms. Using highly trusted content creators to share news of policies addresses both of these issues at once.

Financial educator Rotimi Merriman-Johnson, known as Mr MoneyJar, has recorded videos for policies such as changes to the minimum wage for young people. He began making content before training as a financial adviser, and is keen to emphasise that it‚Äôs not just about relaying any old information. It‚Äôs about consistently sharing quality information that makes a difference to people‚Äôs pockets. ‚ÄúEvery additional year you spend as a content creator, you become more trusted ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs not just about the information, it‚Äôs about the person sharing the information.‚Äù

Political journalists, known as lobby journalists, have been permitted to work in parliament since the 1870s, sit in the press gallery watching the Commons floor, and receive briefings from the prime minister‚Äôs communication staff. The walls of the room where these briefings happen are lined with now-defunct telephone booths designed to allow reporters to file their copy down the phone. Desks in the members‚Äô lobby, the room in which MPs gather before entering the Commons chamber, are pitted with now-dry ink wells. The bowels of Westminster are knotted with internet cables that sit ‚Äì quite precariously ‚Äì on top of old steam pipes. Inviting creators into the heart of government is yet another iteration of British politics and its institutions responding to technological innovation.

Since their introduction more than 20 years ago, social media sites have evolved into ‚Äúcontent platforms‚Äù. Once, Myspace, Facebook et al were spaces to connect with friends; with the advent of Instagram, they became places to follow lifestyle ‚Äúinfluencers‚Äù; now they are platforms that host a never-ending stream of ‚Äúcontent‚Äù. Some of the best creators lean hard into specialisms and niches, and present themselves as experts in specific areas. According to Diane Banks, the chief executive of talent management agency Northbank Talent: ‚ÄúWe are in the age of the expert content creator.‚Äù

In many ways, these expert creators are the perfect interlocutors for the Starmer government: they are technocratic and emphatically apolitical. As creator Cameron Smith says: ‚ÄúWhen I go into these rooms I‚Äôm representing my audience‚Äôs interests, not the interests of these political parties.‚Äù In fact, being non-ideological is integral to the business model. Talent management agencies shy away from polemicists as they are difficult to monetise. Brands don‚Äôt like to work with opinions. In this sense, the UK is treading a different path from the US, as the White House has seen an exodus of mainstream reporters who are being replaced by regime-friendly influencers and commentators.

Of course, the creators acknowledge the tension between pushing politicians on issues their audiences may be facing and needing to maintain access. This is especially pressing at a time when so many people feel knots tighten in their stomachs whenever they check their bank balances. There are more than a dozen major news publications in the UK, but millions of individual creators. It‚Äôs hard for a government to ignore ‚Äì to pick an example out of nowhere ‚Äì the Guardian for long, but easy to cast aside a creator who isn‚Äôt playing ball.

Creator Mat Gay says: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a difficult question because while I would love to push a bit harder and talk a little bit more about the things that people are worrying about, to me it‚Äôs more important to just get them to the table.‚Äù Gabriel Nussbaum believes things are shifting. ‚ÄúThey were a little bit rigid at the start,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThey said: ‚ÄòCan you submit five questions that you‚Äôd want to ask Rachel Reeves?‚Äô, for example. And then they‚Äôd come back and say: ‚ÄòDo you mind not asking question four and five?‚Äô‚Äù But now, he finds he is given the freedom to question politicians. A government spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe are engaging with content creators, as well as journalists to reach new audiences, ensure we are held to account in a changing media landscape and keep the public better informed about government policies.‚Äù

Talking to these creators, I get the sense that they‚Äôre diligent and dutiful to their audiences, focused on the policy rather than the politics. Rather than political journalists, they seem to have 

Kirsty Major is a deputy Opinion editor for the Guardian

title: The QuickShot II joystick review ‚Äì 80s clicks and waggles lovingly recreated
description:
The updated QuickShot II brings retro gameplay into the modern era while preserving the no-frills button smashing and endearing flaws that fans loved
Nostalgia is big in the modern games industry. It‚Äôs ironic that the most technologically obsessed art form on the planet is just as watery-eyed about the past as cinema and music. And to prove it here is the new version of the legendary QuickShot II, a plasticky joystick from the early 1980s that wasn‚Äôt even that good the first time round. It was, however, cheap and it resembled an actual fighter plane control stick with its multiple fire buttons and ergonomic shaft. If you wanted a rugged and precise controller you‚Äôd go for the Competition Pro, but that one didn‚Äôt let you pretend to be in Star Wars or Airwolf.
fullText:
The updated QuickShot II brings retro gameplay into the modern era while preserving the no-frills button smashing and endearing flaws that fans loved

Nostalgia is big in the modern games industry. It‚Äôs ironic that the most technologically obsessed art form on the planet is just as watery-eyed about the past as cinema and music. And to prove it here is the new version of the legendary QuickShot II, a plasticky joystick from the early 1980s that wasn‚Äôt even that good the first time round. It was, however, cheap and it resembled an actual fighter plane control stick with its multiple fire buttons and ergonomic shaft. If you wanted a rugged and precise controller you‚Äôd go for the Competition Pro, but that one didn‚Äôt let you pretend to be in Star Wars or Airwolf. Plus, the QuickShot II had suckers on its base so you could stick it to your cockpit control panel ‚Äì sorry, I mean MDF computer table.

The new QuickShot II from Retro Games and Plaion Replai is almost an exact replica in terms of its dimensions. You can grasp it in your fist and wrap your thumb and forefinger around its large red buttons. Yes, you can stick it to your table; the designers have even included the original auto-fire switch at the rear for players who weren‚Äôt prepared to hit the fire button repeatedly while playing Green Beret.

It has been tastefully updated, though. The two fire buttons on the stick can now be separately configured ‚Äì a feature I yearned for as a young Commodore 64 fanatic so that I could independently control the laser and bombs in Skramble. There are also six buttons on the base, which align with standard joypad layouts, and the USB cable means you can plug it into a PC or any of the modern computer remakes released by Retro Games, such as the C64 or Spectrum. I tested it with the latter and have already spent many hours blasting through Ant Attack, Pheenix and Head over Heels.

In terms of build quality, it‚Äôs a good balance of necessary updates and respectful nonaction. The stick itself has plenty of travel (you have to push it quite far to register movement), which is just as I remember. This made the QuickShot famously unsuitable for joystick-waggling titles such as Daley Thompson‚Äôs Decathlon as you had to move it a long way left and right, often causing damage to the joystick and indignity to yourself. At least now the designers have added microswitches so you get a nice click when the stick moves. The fire buttons, however, still have the same old soft click, and the sound and feel of them is one of the most warmly nostalgic parts of the whole thing. I spent so many hours of my teen years pressing those buttons ‚Äì the sound is as hardwired into my memory as the smell of school dinners or the wash of the ocean against a pier.

I also tried the QuickShot II with Steam and it worked absolutely fine after some simple calibration ‚Äì although the auto-fire proved problematic. It was lovely to play the Steam version of classic shooter Truxton with this stick, returning me to memories of playing arcade games in Blackpool then going home and pretending my computer desk and joystick were an arcade cabinet. You think these feelings are gone but it doesn‚Äôt take much to bring them hurtling back ‚Äì sometimes just a hunk of plastic will do it.

If you‚Äôre looking for a serious modern joystick, this isn‚Äôt it. It‚Äôs low-budget and awkward and, despite an hour of configuring, I couldn‚Äôt get it to work with PC emulation platform RetroArch, which was a shame, though others may manage it. But this is the point: the QuickShot II was not the best joystick, it was the one we could afford. And it looked cool.

I respect that the remake is true to that spirit. It is affordable and a little compromised. But if you owned one back in the day, it is a fun thing to have, and the fourth star in my review is for the absolute raw nostalgia of it. Every time I see it sitting there beside my hi-tech PC and big HD monitor, I smile. It‚Äôs good to have you back, old friend, with all your flaws and shortcomings.

title: Mind launches inquiry into AI and mental health after Guardian investigation
description: Exclusive: England and Wales charity to examine safeguards after Guardian exposed ‚Äòvery dangerous‚Äô advice on Google AI...
fullText:
Exclusive: England and Wales charity to examine safeguards after Guardian exposed ‚Äòvery dangerous‚Äô advice on Google AI Overviews

‚ÄòVery dangerous‚Äô: a Mind mental health expert on Google‚Äôs AI summaries

Mind is launching a significant inquiry into artificial intelligence and mental health after a Guardian investigation exposed how Google‚Äôs AI Overviews gave people ‚Äúvery dangerous‚Äù medical advice.

In a year-long commission, the mental health charity, which operates in England and Wales, will examine the risks and safeguards required as AI increasingly influences the lives of millions of people affected by mental health issues worldwide.

The inquiry ‚Äì the first of its kind globally ‚Äì will bring together the world‚Äôs leading doctors and mental health professionals, as well as people with lived experience, health providers, policymakers and tech companies. Mind says it will aim to shape a safer digital mental health ecosystem, with strong regulation, standards and safeguards.

The launch comes after the Guardian revealed how people were being put at risk of harm by false and misleading health information in Google AI Overviews. The AI-generated summaries are shown to 2 billion people a month, and appear above traditional search results on the world‚Äôs most visited website.

After the reporting, Google removed AI Overviews for some but not all medical searches. Dr Sarah Hughes, chief executive officer of Mind, said ‚Äúdangerously incorrect‚Äù mental health advice was still being provided to the public. In the worst cases, the bogus information could put lives at risk, she said.

Hughes said: ‚ÄúWe believe AI has enormous potential to improve the lives of people with mental health problems, widen access to support, and strengthen public services. But that potential will only be realised if it is developed and deployed responsibly, with safeguards proportionate to the risks.

‚ÄúThe issues exposed by the Guardian‚Äôs reporting are among the reasons we‚Äôre launching Mind‚Äôs commission on AI and mental health, to examine the risks, opportunities and safeguards needed as AI becomes more deeply embedded in everyday life.

‚ÄúWe want to ensure that innovation does not come at the expense of people‚Äôs wellbeing, and that those of us with lived experience of mental health problems are at the heart of shaping the future of digital support.‚Äù

Google has said its AI Overviews, which use generative AI to provide snapshots of essential information about a topic or question, are ‚Äúhelpful‚Äù and ‚Äúreliable‚Äù.

But the Guardian found some AI Overviews served up inaccurate health information and put people at risk of harm. The investigation uncovered false and misleading medical advice across a range of issues, including cancer, liver disease and women‚Äôs health, as well as mental health conditions.

Experts said some AI Overviews for conditions such as psychosis and eating disorders offered ‚Äúvery dangerous advice‚Äù and were ‚Äúincorrect, harmful or could lead people to avoid seeking help‚Äù.

Google is also downplaying safety warnings that its AI-generated medical advice may be wrong, the Guardian found.

Hughes said vulnerable people were being served ‚Äúdangerously incorrect guidance on mental health‚Äù, including ‚Äúadvice that could prevent people from seeking treatment, reinforce stigma or discrimination and in the worst cases, put lives at risk‚Äù.

She added: ‚ÄúPeople deserve information that is safe, accurate and grounded in evidence, not untested technology presented with a veneer of confidence.‚Äù

If you have something to share about this story, you can contact Andrew using one of the following methods.

The Guardian app has a tool to send tips about stories. Messages are end to end encrypted and concealed within the routine activity that every Guardian mobile app performs. This prevents an observer from knowing that you are communicating with us at all, let alone what is being said.

If you don‚Äôt already have the Guardian app, download it (iOS/Android) and go to the menu. Select ‚ÄòSecure Messaging‚Äô.

If you don‚Äôt need a high level of security or confidentiality you can email¬†andrew.gregory@theguardian.com

SecureDrop and other secure methods

If you can safely use the tor network without being observed or monitored you can send messages and documents to the Guardian via our SecureDrop platform.

Finally, our guide at theguardian.com/tips¬†lists several ways to contact us securely, and discusses the pros and cons of each.

The commission, which will run for a year, will gather evidence on the intersection of AI and mental health, and provide an ‚Äúopen space‚Äù where the experience of people with mental health conditions will be ‚Äúseen, recorded and understood‚Äù.

Rosie Weatherley, information content manager at Mind, said that although Googling mental health information ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt perfect‚Äù before AI Overviews, it usually worked well. She said: ‚ÄúUsers had a good chance of clicking through to a credible health website that answered their query, and then went further ‚Äì offering nuance, lived experience, case studies, quotes, social context and an onward journey to support.

‚ÄúAI Overviews replaced that richness with a clinical-sounding summary that gives an illusion of definitiveness. They give the user more of one form of clarity (brevity and plain English), while giving them less of another form of clarity (security in the source of the information, and how much to trust it). It‚Äôs a very seductive swap, but not a responsible one.‚Äù

A Google spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe invest significantly in the quality of AI Overviews, particularly for topics like health, and the vast majority provide accurate information.

‚ÄúFor queries where our systems identify a person might be in distress, we work to display relevant, local crisis hotlines. Without being able to review the examples referenced, we can‚Äôt comment on their accuracy.‚Äù

Jose Alvarado gives brutally honest answer on Pistons' regular season sweep over Knicks
description: We'll see if it matters come playoff time.
fullText:
Jose Alvarado gives brutally honest answer on Pistons' regular season sweep over Knicks originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The New York Knicks suffered their third loss of the season to the Detroit Pistons on Thursday night, a regular-season sweep from their Eastern Conference Rivals.

The biggest problem is that New York hasn't been competitive in all three games against Detroit, losing Thursday night's matchup by 15, January 5's by 31, and February 6's by 28. It's a troubling sign for a team that's supposed to be a top contender in the East.

But it seems the Knicks aren't worried, though, and recent trade acquisition Jose Alvarado downplayed the regular-season series sweep in his media availability after the game.

"Playoffs is a whole different ball game," Alvarado told reporters. "I mean, we're not gonna sit here and say, just because they beat us in regular season, we can't, we're not thinking like that, I don't think like that. So, I mean, when it counts, that's when it matters, so we're gonna play like that."

Even though Alvarado is a new addition to this Knicks team, this isn't new for these guys, especially dating back to last season.

Throughout the 2024-2025 season, New York was swept by both the Boston Celtics and the Cleveland Cavaliers in the regular season. The Knicks didn't end up playing Cleveland in the postseason, but took down Boston in six games in the Eastern Conference Semifinals.

If anything, Knicks fans, this is a good sign of things to come in the postseason. If history repeats itself, New York will have a shot at taking down Detroit in the postseason if the two franchises meet.

Though it's important to note that those were¬†Tom Thibodeau's Knicks teams. We'll see if Mike Brown has what it takes to ensure his team turns it up a notch once the playoffs roll around.

title: Takeaways from the Chicago Bulls‚Äô 7th straight loss, including Jaden Ivey‚Äôs DNP and Wes Unseld Jr. filling in
description: For the first time in his NBA career, Chicago Bulls guard Jaden Ivey finished a game with a ‚ÄúDNP ‚Äî coach‚Äôs decision‚Äù next to his name in the box score. The guard did not play in Thursday‚Äôs 110-101 loss to the Toronto Raptors at the United Center despite not being listed on the injury report. Acting coach Wes Unseld Jr. said Ivey‚Äôs absence was purely a basketball decision, but the guard alluded ...
fullText:
For the first time in his NBA career, Chicago Bulls guard Jaden Ivey finished a game with a ‚ÄúDNP ‚Äî coach‚Äôs decision‚Äù next to his name in the box score.

The guard did not play in Thursday‚Äôs 110-101 loss to the Toronto Raptors at the United Center despite not being listed on the injury report. Acting coach Wes Unseld Jr. said Ivey‚Äôs absence was purely a basketball decision, but the guard alluded to lingering knee soreness as a partial cause for the healthy scratch. Ivey said he is still practicing fully despite the injury and believes he is fully available to play.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure people can call it out that I‚Äôm not the same player as I used to be,‚Äù Ivey, 24, said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why. I‚Äôm not the JI I used to be. But the old JI is dead. I‚Äôm alive in Christ. ‚Ä¶ No matter how many DNP‚Äôs I don‚Äôt get to play or no matter how many points I score, those things are a temporary thing.‚Äù

This could be a new status quo for the Bulls, whose roster includes six guards. Unseld spoke with the team at shootaround Thursday morning to address the reality that players might see a reduction in their minutes as the team attempts to figure out healthy rotations. The decision was made in conjunction with coach Billy Donovan, who was not with the team following the death of his father.

But Ivey said he was not informed heading into the game that he would not play at all against the Raptors.

‚ÄúObviously going into it you‚Äôve got to look at who‚Äôs on the roster,‚Äù Ivey said. ‚ÄúThis team has a lot of guards, so going into it I‚Äôm kind of just thrown in. I do my job to the glory of God so I‚Äôm ready for whenever my name is called. Whenever (the) coach needs me, calls my name, I‚Äôll be out there to play. Getting traded, that‚Äôs what happens in the NBA. You get traded, the organization figures out what the team needs and they make their adjustments.‚Äù

Sixteen days ago, Ivey was logging 16.8 minutes per game for the best team in the East. The Bulls traded for him with the intention of investing in his future as a young playmaker. And Ivey had been decently productive in his first four games with the Bulls, averaging 11.5 points and four assists. He joked about his hefty workload after playing 33 minutes in his debut against the Raptors on Feb. 5 and averaged 28.8 minutes for the Bulls before the All-Star break.

As a restricted free agent this summer, Ivey is not guaranteed to return to Chicago for the 2026-27 season. But the Bulls have been publicly insistent that they plan to test out every player they acquired at the deadline as a potential option to be re-signed in the offseason.

Ivey shied away from expressing how Thursday‚Äôs game ‚Äî or further lack of playing time ‚Äî could affect his feelings toward the Bulls in free agency, repeatedly turning to his faith as a guiding post among uncertainty on the court.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really trust the NBA setting,‚Äù Ivey said. ‚ÄúI trust the Lord. That‚Äôs the main thing. He places me where I need to be. ‚Ä¶ When moves are made behind the scenes of trades and stuff, I don‚Äôt trust that part. You can‚Äôt trust it, because it‚Äôs not in your hands. It‚Äôs not in my hands to make moves or trade myself or put myself in a certain position. I leave that up to the Lord.‚Äù

Who are the 7 new Chicago Bulls? Meet Jaden Ivey, Anfernee Simons and the rest of the deadline additions.

Thursday marked a season-high-tying seventh consecutive loss in their first game back from the All-Star break. Despite forcing a clutch finish with a 7-0 run in the final stretch of the fourth quarter, the Bulls couldn‚Äôt fend off a 31-point game from Brandon Ingram, who knocked down a dagger 3-pointer with 35.5 seconds remaining.

The Bulls have lost 10 of their last 11 games, a result directly tied to their decision to dump the majority of their players on expiring contracts at the trade deadline. And the schedule will only get harder this weekend when the Bulls host a home back-to-back against the Detroit Pistons and the New York Knicks.

Here are three more takeaways from the loss.

Unseld helmed the Bulls for the game in the stead of coach Billy Donovan, who was away from the team to spend time with his family after the death of his father, Bill Donovan Sr.

The elder Donovan died Saturday at age 85. He was a member of the Boston College Hall of Fame after captaining the team and graduating in 1962 as the program‚Äôs third-leading scorer.

Donovan Jr. is expected to return Friday to Chicago and could resume his coaching duties for this weekend‚Äôs back-to-back.

The Bulls returned to a vague semblance of their former selves with guards Giddey and Jones back on the court. The pair had been sidelined for a considerable stretch of the season (19 games for Giddey, 11 for Jones) before the All-Star break with hamstring injuries.

Jalen Smith also returned to the lineup after missing five of the last seven games before the break with a calf injury. Although his absence was less extensive, it had a bigger impact because of his status as the only remaining center on the roster from before the trade deadline.

Unseld was cagey about the playing-time restrictions for all three players, declining to share details about any of their medical limits during his pregame news conference. Giddey played 21 minutes, 25 seconds and Jones 21:51 while Smith logged 24:20.

Both guards failed to score in the first half. Jones warmed into his offense in the third quarter and finished with 12 points, but Smith and Giddey struggled to connect on their shots. Smith finished with nine points on 2-for-6 shooting while Giddey scored five points on 1-for-7 shooting. Giddey added five assists while committing four turnovers.

The Bulls still aren‚Äôt playing cohesive basketball. In fact, it‚Äôs unclear whether they‚Äôll be able to accomplish that feat ‚Äî piecing together a collective identity out of a haphazard puzzle of misfit deadline acquisitions ‚Äî before the regular season ends.

Against the Raptors, that translated into sloppy basketball. The first quarter took 35 minutes to be completed as both teams combined for nine fouls and 13 turnovers. Collin Sexton turned the ball over three times in that span, including an eight-second violation when he failed to advance the ball past half-court. The Bulls gave up 28 points off 20 turnovers for the game.

Matas Buzelis once again receded in a loss, scoring only four points in nearly 31:20 before getting pulled from the closing lineup. Anfernee Simons (20 points) and Isaac Okoro (16) combined for nearly one-third of the team‚Äôs scoring, but neither player looked comfortable in their respective rotations.

title: Celtics hold off late rally to down Warriors in first game since ASG
description: The Boston Celtics defeated the Golden State Warriors in their first game after the All-Star break, their first in a 4-game road trip.
fullText:
The Boston Celtics returned from the All-Star break and came out firing on all cylinders against the Golden State Warriors, who were without Steph Curry. It was the first meeting of the season between Boston and Golden State, and a tale of two teams trending in much different directions.

Jaylen Brown continued his hot streak, while Payton Pritchard once again grabbed the spotlight during a West Coast road trip. The Celtics were in control for most of the game, but the Warriors came out with heavy pressure and their best full court performance in the fourth quarter to make it a close game behind a 15-0 run.

In the end, while all of Boston's starters appeared as if they'd be on the bench for the final quarter, most of the starting unit was on the floor at the end of the game. Boston would pull off the victory, but it certainly came with a bit more pressure than expected in the end.

Jaylen Brown's statement: Coming right out of the All-Star break, Jaylen Brown put his foot on the pedal and never let up with his triple-double performance. Brown also added to his current streak, his 17th straight game with at least 20 points, the fourth-longest active streak in the league currently. During All-Star weekend, much was made about the potential return of Jayson Tatum, but Brown continued his incredible play this season and guided the Celtics to yet another victory.

Effective shooting: Boston shot incredibly well in this game, shooting over 50% from the field, over 40% from 3-point range, and just under 90% from the free throw line, making an impact at every scoring level. Four players scored in double digits in this one, led by Payton Pritchard who shot 10-18 from the field, putting together a game-high 26 points.

Paint dominance: In his post-game interview, Jaylen Brown raved about his ability to get in the paint and benefit from several layup opportunities, and it didn't stop there. Boston dominated in the paint in every aspect, outscoring Golden State by 14 points down low, and cleaned up the boards, outrebounding the Warriors by 14 as well.

Payton Pritchard and Kristaps Porzingis fighting like brothers ü•π pic.twitter.com/tkJzcm73wY

‚Äî Taylor Snow (@taylorcsnow) February 20, 2026

Boston will continue their West Coast road trip with a visit to the Los Angeles Lakers on Sunday night, the final meeting between the two historic franchises. The Celtics picked up a 21-point victory over the Lakers who were without both Luka Doncic and LeBron James in that first matchup, but both should be expected to play in the primetime matchup on Sunday. It'll be another opportunity for Jaylen Brown who is coming off a triple-double performance against the Warriors, to keep etching his name atop the best players in the league, and MVP conversation this season.

This article originally appeared on Celtics Wire: Celtics hold off late rally to down Warriors in first game since ASG

title: Kings set franchise record with 15th straight loss, a 37-point pasting by Magic
description: The Kings haven't won a game since Jan. 16.
fullText:
Among a horde of tanking NBA teams, the Sacramento Kings stand alone with the worst record in the NBA. It didn't get any better Thursday.

The Kings extended their losing streak to 15 games with a 131-94 defeat by the Orlando Magic, breaking the franchise record for consecutive losses. That low mark was previously held by two different streaks during the team's days of operation as the Cincinnati Royals.

Sacramento hasn't won a game since Jan. 16, a 128-115 win over the similarly futile Washington Wizards. To give a sports fan some perspective on how long ago that was, the NFL divisional round started the next day.

Thursday's loss was the most lopsided of the bunch with a 37-point scoring margin. Five of the 15 were actually by fewer than five points, but the Kings couldn't get it done.

As a reminder, the Kings fired current New York Knicks head coach Mike Brown after his team suffered a ... five-game losing streak.

The Kings will get their next chance to break the streak with a road game against Victor Wembanyama and the San Antonio Spurs on Saturday. After that, their next three opponents are the Memphis Grizzlies, Houston Rockets and Dallas Mavericks.

There is hardly reason to expect an improvement in the latter stage of the season, beyond the idea that an NBA team just can't be this bad. The Kings announced Wednesday that All-Star big man Domantas Sabonis had undergone season-ending surgery to repair the torn meniscus in his left knee. Zach LaVine, the team's leading scorer, is already out for the season following a hand surgery.

With those two out, Thursday offered a vision of how the Kings will be operating moving forward. DeMar DeRozan scored 13 points on 3-of-11 shooting. Russell Westbrook had 5 points on 2-of-8 shooting, with 1 assist and 3 turnovers. The bench scored 30 points on a combined 9-of-29 shooting with 8 assists and 9 turnovers.

A bright spot might have been rookie Maxime Reynaud, who started at center in Sabonis' place and posted 17 points on 8-of-13 shooting with 14 rebounds and 4 assists. The Kings were outscored by 14 points in his 39 minutes on the floor, which was actually tied for the team's second-best plus/minus among the 10 players who got minutes.

It's tempting to say the Kings won't even be trying for the rest of the season, but that's not exactly how it works. Ownership and the executive suite might not mind more of the same, which would guarantee them a top-5 pick in the loaded 2026 NBA Draft, but the players still have plenty of reason to compete. This just happens to be an extremely broken roster right now.

There is now quite some distance between Sacramento and the rest of the NBA in the standings. The Wizards, Brooklyn Nets, Indiana Pacers and New Orleans Pelicans all have 15 wins as of Thursday night, with the Kings three wins clear of their closest "competition" for the lottery's top position.

title: Mount Pulaski rolls to win No. 29, 1A regional title over Stew-Stras
description: Mount Pulaski scorched Stewardson-Strasburg to win the Class 1A regional title on Thursday.
fullText:
MOUNT PULASKI ‚Äî¬†If Ryan McVickers needed an edge to push his Mount Pulaski¬†girls¬†basketball team a little harder as the regular season¬†came to a close, he got it.

The Hilltoppers were cruising along, piling¬†up win after¬†win after¬†win. First, the team went 10-0, then 15-0, then 20-0. Finally, with a win over Moweaqua Central A&M, Mount Pulaski got win No. 25 out of 25 games played.

Nothing was stopping the Hilltoppers until Clinton did, in the team‚Äôs 26th¬†game. When the Mount Pulaski team exited the DeWitt County school gymnasium with¬†49-36 loss on Feb. 9, McVickers knew he had what he needed: motivation, a reason to tell the players that¬†they‚Äôre¬†good, but can be beaten and can be better.¬†Instead, the players were ready on the¬†same page.

‚ÄúI think the loss at Clinton was kind of that extra motivation that we needed,‚Äù McVickers said. ‚ÄúWe were just kind of rolling right along and beating teams¬†pretty easily, and then they¬†kind of gave¬†us that wake-up call on their floor ‚Äî a bigger 2A team.

‚ÄúI walked in the locker room, and they were mad.¬†I mean, they were mad after that loss. Heck, we were sitting there at 25-1, and for them to be mad, I¬†knew that¬†that was a great sign.‚Äù

More: Carlinville feels Reels good in regional title win over Williamsville

What does perfection look like? McVickers will¬†probably¬†say¬†that Thursday night¬†wasn‚Äôt¬†perfection, and if that‚Äôs not perfection, Mount Pulaski could have an extended postseason run as the¬†top-seeded¬†Hilltoppers throttled¬†No. 5 Stewardson-Strasburg 50-27 to win the Class 1A Mount Pulaski Regional championship. It was¬†the school‚Äôs third title in five seasons.

It was¬†also¬†the Hilltoppers‚Äô fourth straight win after that Clinton loss and takes their record to 29-1. ¬†Mount Pulaski faces No. 2 Hume Shiloh (19-6) on Tuesday at 6 p.m. in the Argenta-Oreana Sectional semifinals.

‚ÄúAfter we lost to Clinton, that really flipped our switch, and we just kept on rolling,‚Äù Mount Pulaski junior Addy Brown said. ‚ÄúPlaying our game throughout the rest of the season is what¬†we're¬†going to do.‚Äù

Brown led the Hilltoppers with 16 points. She connected on four 3-pointers and grabbed seven rebounds, four on the offensive end.

Mount Pulaski got the win through intense pressure defense that can stretch the length of the court, getting extra possessions through turnovers and offensive rebounds, and an unselfishness that led to beautiful¬†ball movement, resulting in open shots and easy looks at the basket.

‚ÄúWhen our defense is flying around and anticipating that next pass, we really do a nice job of jumping in those passing lanes,‚Äù McVickers said. ‚ÄúOnce we get the steal,¬†we're¬†off, and¬†we're¬†flying, and¬†we're¬†running, and we can get those turnovers and then convert them into easy transition buckets.‚Äù

In the second quarter alone,¬†freshman¬†Ella Martin snuck into the paint twice with the Hatchets completely unaware¬†for¬†a pair of easy layups.¬†Mount Pulaski rebounded three of its own misses on the same possession to further stymie Stew-Stras, had 17 offensive boards and outrebounded the Hatchets 36-23.

More: Calvary's rebounding gets offensive in big win at Mount Pulaski

When Stew-Stras¬†wasn‚Äôt¬†turning the ball over due to Mount Pulaski‚Äôs pressure, the Hilltoppers were outright taking it from the Hatchets, like when Alyson Murphy overpowered point guard Cameron Carey and ripped the ball out of her hands.

McVickers also has the luxury of a deep roster of scorers. While Brown and Elayna Marten (11 points) combined to score 27, McVickers knows he can count¬†on any of the players on the floor to score if needed. The Hatchets¬†focused its defensive effort on¬†Murphy, and the¬†senior finished with just four points.¬†But sophomore Olivia Smith had¬†eight,¬†Brown had¬†six and¬†Audrey Cooper, a junior, had five.

‚ÄúOur main thing is just energy all the time and always bringing our best efforts and just always showing up for each other, working as hard as we can all the time,‚Äù Marten said, then added that the team really focused on improving several areas of its game ahead of the postseason.

‚ÄúI would say just always looking for that one extra pass, always boxing out every single possession no matter what, and just always¬†critiquing¬†the¬†little things¬†and making sure¬†we're¬†improving in all areas and doing all the¬†little things.‚Äù

Brown said the Hilltoppers come out in a fury to start the¬†game¬†knowing that early effort could pay off by watching the end of the game from the bench, as they were able to¬†in¬†the running-clock win.

‚ÄúOur press is really good; we fly,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúGetting those steals early and getting up by 15, 20 early is what really brings our motivation and energy to go throughout the rest of the game.‚Äù

Mount Pulaski is looking for its first sectional title since 2013 when the Hilltoppers finished second in the Class 1A state tournament.

Contact Ryan Mahan: 788-1546,¬†ryan.mahan@sj-r.com, Twitter.com/RyanMahanSJR.

This article originally appeared on State Journal-Register: IHSA girls basketball: Mount Pulaski rolls to regional title win

title: Watch: Kristaps Porzingis dunks down first points as a Warrior
description: Golden State's new big man got on the board on Thursday night with a dunk against the Celtics.
fullText:
On Thursday night, Chase Center welcomed the newest member of the Golden State Warriors to the court with the debut of newly acquired 7-foot-2 big man, Kristaps Porzingis. After being traded to the Warriors from the Atlanta Hawks at the NBA trade deadline, Porzingis missed four games in Golden State as he continued to rehab his Achilles injury.

After practicing and scrimmaging during the All-Star break, the former All-Star big man was set to make his highly-anticiapted debut with the Warriors on Thursday night against his former team, the Boston Celtics. Porzingis came off the bench, checking into the game at the start of the second quarter to a huge ovation from the Chase Center crowd in San Francisco.

Late in the second quarter, Porzingis got on the board as an official member of the Warriors with a dunk at the rim.

Kristaps Porzingis' first bucket as a Dub üôå pic.twitter.com/gBJGpV2V2e

‚Äî Warriors on NBCS (@NBCSWarriors) February 20, 2026

After his early dunk, Porzingis showed off his long-distance shooting, burying his first 3-pointer as a member of the Warriors before halftime.

Porzingis from downtown ‚òîÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/WIutbNhCyM

‚Äî Warriors on NBCS (@NBCSWarriors) February 20, 2026

In Golden State's ugly 121-110 loss to Boston, Porzingis finished with 12 points on 5-of-9 shooting from the field with two made 3-pointers to go along with a rebound and an assist in 17 minutes against the Celtics.

This post originally appeared on Warriors Wire!

title: TST Images: The USC Trojans defeat the Wisconsin Badgers 66-59, at Galen Center
description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF.
fullText:
LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - The USC Trojans defeated the Wisconsin Badgers 66-59, at Galen Center on Thursday February 19, 2026 and The Sporting Tribune's Amber Rodriguez was there to capture the following images.

Amber Rodriguez - The Sporting Tribune

USC guard Kennedy Smith (11) defends during a Big Ten college basketball game against the Wisconsin Badgers, Thursday February 19, 2026 in Los Angeles.

Amber Rodriguez - The Sporting Tribune

title: Gable Steveson remains undefeated with a first-round finish at MFL 3
description: Olympic gold medalist Gable Steveson secured another first-round TKO victory, keeping hope alive for a UFC debut next.
fullText:
The Gable Steveson hype train is full steam ahead, and the next stop could be in the UFC's octagon after making quick work of another opponent.

In the main event of Mexico Fight League 3, Steveson (3-0) took on Hugo Lezama in a heavyweight bout at Showcenter Complex in Monterrey, Mexico. Lezama (11-4) was Steveson's most experienced opponent yet, but that really didn't matter for the hottest heavyweight MMA prospect in the game today. With UFC legend Jon Jones in his corner, Steveson ended the fight at 3:50 in the opening round by TKO.

Lezama offered a few big, sloppy windups and even connected with a spinning back kick to the head. Steveson walked through it all, though, and calmly took control of the fight on the mat with heavy ground and pound. After letting Lezama work through a few positions from his back, the referee decided to stop the fight after Stevenson opened a cut and began turning up the volume of his ground strikes.

It was like another day at the office for Steveson, whose celebration was not much more than a few smiles. During his post-fight interview, he said he plans to get back to work on a few things while he awaits what comes next.

What's next could be his UFC debut.

The promotion has not hidden its interest in having the Olympic gold medalist wrestler on its roster, but wanted to see him get a little more experience in MMA competition before welcoming him face the experienced opposition in the UFC. He is now 3-0 in MMA competition, plus a win under the custom ruleset of Dirty Boxing Championship. Steveson has won each fight in the first round.

Steveson has said he would love to make his debut at the upcoming UFC White House event in June, which would be a massive introduction to the audience.

This article originally appeared on MMA Junkie: Gable Steveson grows to 3-0 in MMA with potential UFC debut on horizon

title: District 1-6A Play-In Update: Franklin, Eastwood secure playoff spots
description: EL PASO, Texas (KTSM) ‚Äî After a wild Tuesday night in District 1-6A boys basketball, Coronado, Franklin, Montwood, and Eastwood all finished district play tied for second place. With Eastlake already securing a playoff spot as district champions, these four teams were battling for the final three playoff positions. The scenario was simple: win your [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
EL PASO, Texas (KTSM) ‚Äî After a wild Tuesday night in District 1-6A boys basketball, Coronado, Franklin, Montwood, and Eastwood all finished district play tied for second place.

With Eastlake already securing a playoff spot as district champions, these four teams were battling for the final three playoff positions. The scenario was simple: win your first play-in game and you‚Äôre in. Lose, and it comes down to one final game.

In Thursday night‚Äôs results, Eastwood defeated Coronado 41-34, securing their playoff spot, while Franklin beat Montwood 52-38 to also advance.

Eastwood and Franklin are set to play each other in a seeding game on Friday at 7:30 p.m. at Bel Air High School.

That leaves Montwood and Coronado facing off in a do-or-die matchup for the final playoff spot. The game is scheduled for Friday at 6 p.m. at Bel Air High School.

title: What‚Äôs your favorite sandwich to eat while watching a Notre Dame Football game?
description: We all have our favorite thing to eat while watching Notre Dame Football‚Ä¶ here‚Äôs mine, but what‚Äôs yours?
fullText:
I know what you‚Äôre thinking‚Ä¶ here comes some more PEAK Notre Dame Football off-season content, but even if you‚Äôre right, there‚Äôs a better reason we‚Äôre here.

I don‚Äôt quite remember if this is something I have already talked about on the podcast, but after watching this insanely good video about an insanely good-sounding sandwich‚Ä¶ we need to talk about this.

So while I titled this post with a Notre Dame Football hook, all I really want to know is what your favorite sandwich is that you make at home (sorry ‚Äî the Frisco Melt from Steak n Shake isn‚Äôt allowed here).

Is it simple?
Is is big?
Is it the beginning of a horror film?
What‚Äôs your favorite sandwich?

Going back to the Jeff Daniels sandwich and why this hit me like a ton of bricks, I give you mine which was handed down to me by my father.

‚Äî 2 slices of white bread (the cheaper the better)
‚Äî Peanut butter
‚Äî 2 slices of bologna
‚Äî Yellow mustard
‚Äî Colby Jack cheese slice

Don‚Äôt knock it until you try it, and yes‚Ä¶ this wonderful hand basket has seen plenty of Notre Dame football games as I try to pass the tradition on to my own two sons.

Give me a shout in the comments below with your favorite ‚Äî bonus points if you have a Notre Dame themed name.

title: Cunningham stars as NBA-leading Pistons ease past Knicks
description: A dominant Cade Cunningham scored 42 points as the NBA-leading Detroit Pistons swatted aside the New York Knicks 126-111 Thursday on the basketball league's return from its brief All-Star Game break.Thursday's games were the first since the NBA regular season briefly paused for the All-Star Game weekend.
fullText:
A dominant Cade Cunningham scored 42 points as the NBA-leading Detroit Pistons swatted aside the New York Knicks 126-111 Thursday on the basketball league's return from its brief All-Star Game break.

Billed as a must-watch clash between two Eastern Conference-vying rivals each in red-hot form, the game at Madison Square Garden became an exhibition for Cunningham, who also provided 13 assists and eight rebounds.

The 24-year-old burnished his credentials as a Most Valuable Player contender, helping a young, surprise-package Pistons side to improve the best record in the entire NBA this season so far, to 41-13.

After the game, Cunningham insisted he and his side had proved "nothing" yet.

"It's regular season, so we just have to keep on chipping at it, keep on growing, keep on getting better and preparing for the postseason," he said.

"We're off to a great start. Obviously, we feel great about that. But everything is to come."

Despite their blistering form, Detroit -- wholly reconstructed after finishing rock-bottom of the Eastern Conference just two years ago -- are still few pundits' top pick to win the title.

They were also without forward Isaiah Stewart and All-Star center Jalen Duren on Thursday, due to suspensions following a brawl with the Charlotte Hornets during game last week.

"Missing Stew, JD, that's a big part of our team. Big part of why we are where we are. So everyone had to step up," said Cunningham.

And the Knicks had entered the game third in the Eastern Conference, on a run of 10 wins from 12, comparable to the Pistons' 12 from 15 ahead of Thursday's clash.

But Detroit had extra motivation -- revenge after the Knicks knocked them out of the playoffs last year in the first round. The win on Thursday completes a three-win regular season sweep over the Knicks.

"If felt great," said Cunningham, who poured in three three-pointers in the first quarter alone. He added two more later in the game, with other highlights including a huge, driving dunk in the third quarter.

Elsewhere, Jaylen Brown recorded a triple-double as the in-form Boston Celtics overwhelmed the Golden State Warriors 121-110.

Consolidating second spot in the Eastern Conference, the Celtics led by as much as 34 points in the third quarter, before the Warriors reduced the deficit but to no avail.

Brown managed 23 points, 13 assists and 15 rebounds, while Payton Pritchard top-scored with 26 from the bench, in the Celtics' seventh win from their past eight games.

Thursday's games were the first since the NBA regular season briefly paused for the All-Star Game weekend.

"It's early, first game back," said Brown.

"I'm just being aggressive, finding my spots," he added.

The Cleveland Cavaliers earned a sixth consecutive win. The Cavs beat the Brooklyn Nets 112-84 to draw level with the Knicks in third place.

Jalen Johnson dominated a 117-107 Atlanta Hawks road win over the Philadelphia 76ers, scoring 32 points, with 10 rebounds, five assists and three steals.

Kevin Durant managed 35 points in the Houston Rockets' 105-101 victory over the Hornets.

In the West,¬†the Sacramento Kings set an unwanted franchise record with a¬†15-game losing streak, after going down 131-94 to the Orlando Magic.

And the second-placed San Antonio Spurs put some pressure on the leaders, Oklahoma City Thunder, with a 121-94 triumph over the Phoenix Suns.

The Spurs' seventh consecutive win takes them to 39-16, still trailing the Thunder on 42-14.

title: An important player for Manchester City got through unscathed against Salford but his future appears uncertain
description: John Stones has once again battled injury throughout the 2025/26 season. The England international has made only 14 appearances for Pep Guardiola‚Äôs Manchester City side in all competitions this seas...
fullText:
John Stones has once again battled injury throughout the 2025/26 season. The England international has made only 14 appearances for Pep Guardiola‚Äôs Manchester City side in all competitions this season. Stones recently returned from an extended injury layoff and played 65 minutes of City‚Äôs 2-0 win over Salford City at the Etihad Stadium in their fourth-round FA Cup tie. John Stones could have an important role to play for Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side for the remainder of this season as they remain in the hunt for four trophies. Looking beyond this season, John Stones‚Äô future seems to lie away from Manchester City, based on a recent report.

It was pleasing to see John Stones start Manchester City‚Äôs match against Salford City. He put in a workmanlike performance as he did his job well as City‚Äôs captain for the day and as a centre-back. It was clear that Stones was rusty, but the fact that he got through 65 minutes unscathed is a major positive for Manchester City. Stones has had a frustrating 25/26 season, so seeing him get through any match without suffering any injury setbacks is a pleasing sight.

Pep Guardiola was happy to see John Stones back on the pitch against Salford City. Guardiola admitted that Stones is someway off his best, but the fact he is back playing is good news. Speaking on John Stone‚Äô return, Guardiola said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good he‚Äôs back. He still needs time. He‚Äôs not the John Stones we knew but that‚Äôs normal. His body language was really good and he had the tempo to fight the duels. After more than two months injured, he played 60 minutes.‚Äù

If John Stones can stay fit and rediscover his best form, he will have an important role to play as Manchester City remain in the hunt in four competitions. Stones offers Pep Guardiola a completely different option at centre-back to any of City‚Äôs other centre-backs. The hope is that the worst of Stones‚Äô injury concerns are behind him so he can play a role across the back end of this season for his team.

Looking further ahead, it does seem that we are in the final stages of John Stones‚Äô Manchester City career. A new report from Mark Brus in his exclusive Daily Briefing column indicates that Stones won‚Äôt be offered a new contract at City. Stones‚Äô current deal is set to expire at the end of this season. Furthermore, Brus reports that Bayern Munich have shown an interest in signing Stones at the end of this season. Bayern are reportedly considering making a move for Stones as they bid to strengthen their defence. AC Milan and Atletico Madrid are also mentioned by Brus as clubs monitoring the situation surrounding John Stones.

What may hinder clubs in the chase to sign John Stones is his wage demands. Mark Brus reports that Everton have been ruled out of the potential race to sign the England international due to this factor. Despite a return to Everton being ruled out, John Stones seemingly has options if his Manchester City career ends at the end of this season. Players at this stage of their careers often look for the right environment to continue progressing. They weigh different opportunities and consider what comes next. Supporters tend to think in similar terms when deciding how to spend their time or money online, whether that means watching football, playing games, or picking up a¬†Steam card online¬†before moving on to their next title. Stones may yet face similar choices abroad as he looks to take the next step after City.

It was pleasing to see John Stones get through Manchester City‚Äôs FA Cup fourth-round win over Salford City unscathed. The hope is that Stones can contribute to his team across the final stages of this season. Given everything that Stones has done for City, he deserves to be a contributor as Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side chases honours on multiple fronts. The end may be coming for John Stones‚Äô time at Manchester City. If it is, it would be better to see him have one last hurrah at City rather than spend his time on the treatment table.

title: Fan Letters: Concerns Surrounding Sunderland‚Äôs Wheelchair Ticketing Policy
description: RR reader Niall Taylor is concerned about a lack of accessibility for Lads‚Äô fans when following the team away from home
fullText:
I‚Äôm a wheelchair user who regularly attends away games and has done so for many years.

This season, Sunderland AFC have changed their approach to away ticket sales for wheelchair supporters.

Even when wheelchair-accessible tickets are still available, they‚Äôre not being sold once the general away allocation for non-disabled supporters has ‚Äúsold out.‚Äù I‚Äôve been told this is because allowing wheelchair supporters to buy these tickets would be ‚Äúunfair on other supporters.‚Äù

Wheelchair allocations are already extremely limited.

For example, an away allocation of around 2,500 tickets may include as few as sixteen wheelchair spaces. From years of attending away games, I know these wheelchair allocations rarely sell out and a clear example is Oxford away this season.

After tickets sold out in Phase Two, I was refused a wheelchair ticket despite eight of the thirteen wheelchair spaces still being available at the time. This is a noticeable change from previous seasons in League One and the Championship, where wheelchair supporters were still able to purchase available wheelchair tickets even after the general allocation had sold out.

The current policy results in wheelchair spaces being left empty while disabled supporters are excluded from attending matches. I believe this raises serious questions around accessibility, fairness and equal access for Sunderland supporters.

Ed‚Äôs Note [Phil]: Hi, Niall. Thank you for your letter.

This is clearly an extremely important issue and it‚Äôs unfortunate to hear that you weren‚Äôt able to be accommodated for the FA Cup game at Oxford ‚Äî a game during which everyone should‚Äôve been given the chance to support the team on the road.

Without knowing the exact ins and outs of why this policy has seemingly been changed and any possible logistical reasoning, what I will say is that the club certainly has a duty of care to all fans and moving forward, it‚Äôs imperative that nobody is excluded or made to feel unwelcome or a burden. That‚Äôs the very last thing that our club should stand for.

I think I‚Äôd better stop reading other Sunderland fans‚Äô posts and blogs, because some of the rubbish I‚Äôve read about us suddenly being in a relegation fight is ridiculous!

As I‚Äôve said before, we have enough class in the team to finish the season pretty comfortably. The plan at the start was to avoid relegation and we‚Äôve nearly done that, plus we might have a nice cup run on the go.

I‚Äôll say it again: Keep the faith ‚Äòtil the end ‚Äî and FTM forever!

Ed‚Äôs Note [Phil]: Hi, John. Thank you for getting in touch.

Perhaps it‚Äôs a result of the scars left by what happened almost a decade ago, but until we reach the much-discussed total of forty points (and possibly forty two, just to be absolutely certain) I wouldn‚Äôt criticise any Sunderland fan for being a little edgy.

Of course, we have what feels like a good run of games coming up, during which we‚Äôve got an excellent chance of picking up the six points we‚Äôll possibly need, so let‚Äôs see what happens, and hopefully the Lads can get back to winning ways in the league against Fulham on Sunday!

title: Packers induct 28th member of Fan HOF
description: GREEN BAY, Wis. (WFRV) ‚Äì Bleeding green and gold is par for the course here in Northeast Wisconsin, but on Thursday afternoon one cheesehead stood above all the rest. The Packers announced their latest inductee into the Green Bay Packers Fan Hall of Fame. There were 10 finalists. This year‚Äôs Fan Hall of Fame inductee [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
GREEN BAY, Wis. (WFRV) ‚Äì Bleeding green and gold is par for the course here in Northeast Wisconsin, but on Thursday afternoon one cheesehead stood above all the rest.

The Packers announced their latest inductee into the Green Bay Packers Fan Hall of Fame. There were 10 finalists.

This year‚Äôs Fan Hall of Fame inductee was Patrick Suplicki from Stevens Point. He told Local 5 News that becoming a Packers fan was a birthright in his family.

‚ÄúIn our family, you were always a Packers fan from birth, you were nothing else,‚Äù Patrick said.

He said he became a Packers fan at age three and has bled green and gold ever since. He‚Äôs been going to games at Lambeau Field since 1972 and said that watching Reggie White and Bart Starr play were among his favorite Packers memories.

Bay Area boys hockey upsets NDA to advance to sectionals

His dad Elgie was the one who got him hooked on the Packers and taught him the importance of being loyal to your team. Patrick began renovating his basement at his home to turn it into a Packers man cave. He stopped the project in 2003 when his father passed away, but eventually picked the project up and completed it to honor his father.

Patrick‚Äôs basement has become the place for his friends and family to gather for Packers games. He said he prides himself on nurturing the next generation of Packers fans and including his two daughters.

‚ÄúIt was kind of a rule to be a Packer fan in the house,‚Äù his daughter Patrice said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we could have entertained any other team even if we wanted to.‚Äù

Patrick is also a cancer survivor and says that being able to look forward to Packers games help him win that battle.

‚ÄúI think he thought that would be the biggest thing he did in life,‚Äù Patrice told Local 5 News. ‚ÄúBut now I think this is the biggest thing to be immortalized in the Packers Fan Hall Of Fame.‚Äù

Patrice nominated him for the Packers Fan Hall of Fame. She was able to contact Packers legendary wide receiver Antonio Freeman who recorded a video breaking the news that Patrick was a finalist. He learned the news on Christmas Eve.

Patrice said it was emotional seeing her father get inducted into the Fan Hall of Fame on Thursday afternoon. She said that her dad has always been there for all the big moments in her life, so she was so happy to return the favor and be here on her dad‚Äôs big day.

14 high schoolers gather for Encore Singers Revue in Appleton through Center Stage program

‚ÄúWatching him up there, giving his speech being honored for the amazing man and Packers fan he is,‚Äù she told Local 5 News. ‚ÄúIt was the biggest honor I could have as his daughter and the rest of his family (feels that way too).‚Äù

Patrick reflected on the influence his father had on him over the years to get him to the point where he could become a member of the Packers Fan Hall of Fame.

‚ÄúIt means a lot to me, I wish the one main family member was here but unfortunately we lost him in 2003 (his dad),‚Äù Patrick said. ‚ÄúMy dad I think he would have been awed by this, kicking up his heels because he was the ultimate fan. I‚Äôd like to think he‚Äôd be really proud of us.‚Äù

As part of getting inducted into the team‚Äôs Fan Hall of Fame, he also got four club tickets to a Packers home game this upcoming season, pregame sideline passes, a custom Packers jersey, and a gift card to the Packers pro shop.

Patrick is the 28th member of the Packers Fan Hall of Fame.
